name: NPR
text:
When his close friend died, Roddy Doyle and his friends went to the pub.

"It seems like a totally inadequate way ... to mark the death of a friend — to go off and get drunk. But on the other hand, what is an adequate way to mark the death of a friend?"
https://t.co/fy00Sw8DNL

name: NPR
text:
A virtual bake sale called Bakers Against Racism started with a goal of 80 participants. Now, thousands of professional and home bakers around the world are raising money for organizations that support Black lives.
https://t.co/VuYKTwzWtP

name: NPR
text: DACA recipient Tobore Oweh is hopeful yet realistic about what this Supreme Court decision means for her. More of her chat with @NPRitsbeenamin host Sam Sanders. https://t.co/UV0IwIv7sE https://t.co/SnAAdGfaWa

name: NPR
text: Trump's reelection message was as dark as his 2016 convention speech and continually came back to one thing — inciting the culture war. https://t.co/1DvjYzBuET

name: NPR
text:
In 1992, Arsenal commissioned a mural designed to look like fans in the stadium. But there was a significant oversight. @OnlyAGameNPR
https://t.co/UUiq4erO6q

name: NPR
text: More than three hours of personal accounts, calls to action, and sermons put economic inequality at the center of a range of issues troubling the U.S. and the world. https://t.co/vfXKRtrlkv

name: NPR
text:
Archivists found the original handwritten General Order No. 3 buried in the stacks of the National Archives Building.

The order, issued in Galveston on June 19, 1865, informed the people of Texas that all enslaved people were now free.
https://t.co/OeQWJCkrkJ

name: NPR
text:
If we don't interrupt the systems we live within, then we're complicit in them, says Robin DiAngelo, the author of "White Fragility."

"In that way, we can say that nice white people who do nothing further to challenge racism are racist."
https://t.co/XI7a26SZV8

name: NPR
text:
"Certainly in the television era, it's the first time that we've had a president who's been so willing to embrace a racially exclusive perspective on American politics," says Democratic strategist Jamal Simmons.

"That may be turning the tide against him." https://t.co/tI6OVFLpw3

name: NPR
text:
Opinion: A mother reflects on teaching her children the value of human connection — despite living in a time of disconnectedness.
https://t.co/c1T5UmMTLt

name: NPR
text:
Opinion:

The acclaimed jazz trumpeter Terence Blanchard reflects on the past, present and future of the civil rights movement. 

"Many well-meaning people have heard only the melody of our plight, without knowing what the song means for us," he writes.
https://t.co/iroJXoImS6

name: NPR
text:
Elaine Kahn teaches poetry workshops online. She says the impact of the pandemic "was coming out in the poetry in really intense ways ...  I had students just literally writing about being hungry."  
https://t.co/0jKPfg8mr8

name: NPR
text: Evolutionary biologist Dan Riskin answers three questions about Tab diet cola — (that's bat backwards). @waitwait https://t.co/3DNb5pxv7U

name: NPR
text: While politicians spar over the topic and opponents have staged protests against wearing masks, a growing number of scientific studies support the idea that masks are a critical tool in curbing the spread of the coronavirus. https://t.co/pxYNvyBvuP

name: NPR
text:
People in their 20s and 30s are accounting for a larger share of new coronavirus infections in a growing number of cities and states. 
https://t.co/OBeNrp5Rfx

name: NPR
text:
The Trump campaign billed that a million people had signed up for tickets to the Tulsa rally and built a second stage outside for an overflow crowd. 

But the overflow crowd never materialized and the events outside were called off.
 https://t.co/aHabDQ6S6i

name: NPR
text:
Happy Father's Day. Here's Cat Stevens performing four songs at the Tiny Desk — including his classic, "Father and Son." 
https://t.co/ChTgYRaEPy

name: NPR
text:
Congolese can be arrested for not wearing a mask in public. That makes people uneasy in a country with a history of police brutality. 

So citizens might wear one backward or make one out of an absurd material — a banana leaf — as a political statement. https://t.co/yUpqIy5H08

name: NPR
text: Nelba Marquez-Greene's daughter was killed in the Sandy Hook mass shooting. The protests for racial justice sparked by the police killing of George Floyd bring her hope, but rising hope brings the fear that the nation with move on without any change. https://t.co/B23uEza8Kj
